content.text: Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
Department conducting the course: Information Technology

A Basic module of the bachelor's degree program modules is related to information technology, computer science, data science and fintech.... Discrete mathematics is a branch of Mathematics that studies discrete rather than continuous structures. The course also aims to train thinking capacity and calculation skills and improve the ability to apply mathematical knowledge to analyze and research problems in information technology. The course equips learners with the necessary knowledge, skills, and competencies to study and research related subjects in the training program and continue to higher education. At the end of the course, learners can do a graph network data analysis project.

Seminar talks: The goal is to introduce state-of-the-art applications of discrete mathematics in the modern technology. Besides, invited student-speakers can be included to share about their scientific projects related to the course’s materials.
(40%) Quiz + Midterm: quiz 1 (10%), quiz 2 (10%), project presentation (5%) and midterm (15%).
[1] Richard Johnsonbaugh (2018), Discrete Mathematics, Eighth Edition, Pearson.
[2] Kenneth H. Rosen (2019), Discrete Mathematics and Its Applications, Eighth Edition, McGraw-Hill Education.

cells: The course provides learners basic knowledge about sets, logic, mathematical systems, functions, series, relations, algorithms, number theory, counting problems, Dirichlet's principle, and graph theory.

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: The course provides learners basic knowledge about sets, logic, mathematical systems, functions, series, relations, algorithms, number theory, counting problems, Dirichlet's principle, and graph theory.

cells: The course equips learners with skills in the analysis, classification, and computation of objects: sets, propositions, functions, algorithms, strings, and graphs.

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: The course equips learners with skills in the analysis, classification, and computation of objects: sets, propositions, functions, algorithms, strings, and graphs.

cells: The course page allows learners to apply some algorithms on integers and graphs to solve practical problems such as encoding, finding the shortest path, coloring graphs, minimum tree frames, etc.

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: The course page allows learners to apply some algorithms on integers and graphs to solve practical problems such as encoding, finding the shortest path, coloring graphs, minimum tree frames, etc.

cells: Self-study, work independently, work in groups, take personal responsibility, and be partly responsible for the group, accumulate experience to continue higher learning.

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: Self-study, work independently, work in groups, take personal responsibility, and be partly responsible for the group, accumulate experience to continue higher learning.

cells: Understanding the law, civic responsibility; understanding professional behavior, and community interests. Understanding professional principles and ethics, time management, adapting to a changing work environment, adapting to globalization, and technology revolution 4.0

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: Understanding the law, civic responsibility; understanding professional behavior, and community interests. Understanding professional principles and ethics, time management, adapting to a changing work environment, adapting to globalization, and technology revolution 4.0

cells: Understand the concepts and computational bases of sets and propositions. Understand how sets are represented in computers and know the logic of google's search algorithm etc. Understand conflicting principles except for finding word-numbered parts of a set.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the concepts and computational bases of sets and propositions. Understand how sets are represented in computers and know the logic of google's search algorithm etc. Understand conflicting principles except for finding word-numbered parts of a set.

cells: Understand the fundamental objects of mathematical systems and methods of proof in mathematics.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the fundamental objects of mathematical systems and methods of proof in mathematics.

cells: Understand the basic concepts and properties of functions and binary relationships. Understand how to build several functions with high computational applications, such as a linear pseudo-random function (linear congruence method), a hash function (hash function), and a visa card number check function (calculation of credit card check number).

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the basic concepts and properties of functions and binary relationships. Understand how to build several functions with high computational applications, such as a linear pseudo-random function (linear congruence method), a hash function (hash function), and a visa card number check function (calculation of credit card check number).

cells: Understand the basic concepts and properties of algorithms, the operation of a basic algorithm such as a search, sorting, etc. Understand the object and function of a recursive algorithm.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the basic concepts and properties of algorithms, the operation of a basic algorithm such as a search, sorting, etc. Understand the object and function of a recursive algorithm.

cells: Understand basic concepts, properties, and algorithms in integers. Understand operations in the same radix system and how to convert between different radix systems. Know cryptography and understand how to build the RSA cryptosystem.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand basic concepts, properties, and algorithms in integers. Understand operations in the same radix system and how to convert between different radix systems. Know cryptography and understand how to build the RSA cryptosystem.

cells: Understand how to apply two basic counting principles, permutations, and combinations in counting problems. Understand combinatorics and position generation algorithms to solve some real-world problems. Know how to use Dirichlet's principle to show the existence of a combinatorial configuration.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand how to apply two basic counting principles, permutations, and combinations in counting problems. Understand combinatorics and position generation algorithms to solve some real-world problems. Know how to use Dirichlet's principle to show the existence of a combinatorial configuration.

cells: Understand the basic concepts and properties of graph theory. Understand the application of graphs in information technology, computer science, and data science. Translating graph theory into solving practical problems

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the basic concepts and properties of graph theory. Understand the application of graphs in information technology, computer science, and data science. Translating graph theory into solving practical problems

cells: Proficient in sets, propositions, functions, operations with integers, and radix conversion. Proficient in using the principles of counting, permutations, and combinations to solve counting problems. Have skills in calculating quantities in graphs such as degree, Incidence matrix, adjacency matrix, weight matrix, path, the weighted sum of a tree, tree depth, etc.

column_map.CLOs Description: Proficient in sets, propositions, functions, operations with integers, and radix conversion. Proficient in using the principles of counting, permutations, and combinations to solve counting problems. Have skills in calculating quantities in graphs such as degree, Incidence matrix, adjacency matrix, weight matrix, path, the weighted sum of a tree, tree depth, etc.

cells: Have the skills to read, understand, present, analyze, evaluate an algorithm, and implement it.

column_map.CLOs Description: Have the skills to read, understand, present, analyze, evaluate an algorithm, and implement it.

cells: Apply knowledge and some algorithms about integers to build cryptographic systems such as anagrams or RSA.

column_map.CLOs Description: Apply knowledge and some algorithms about integers to build cryptographic systems such as anagrams or RSA.

cells: Apply combinatorial and permutation algorithms to solve the bag problem, the traveler problem, etc.

column_map.CLOs Description: Apply combinatorial and permutation algorithms to solve the bag problem, the traveler problem, etc.

cells: Apply knowledge of graphs to solve practical problems, such as: Use the problem of finding the shortest path to find the path between two points on the map such as shortest distance or the least time or minimum cost, and using coloring problems in scheduling problems, wave frequency division, using the minimal spanning tree to design water pipelines, highway systems, etc.

column_map.CLOs Description: Apply knowledge of graphs to solve practical problems, such as: Use the problem of finding the shortest path to find the path between two points on the map such as shortest distance or the least time or minimum cost, and using coloring problems in scheduling problems, wave frequency division, using the minimal spanning tree to design water pipelines, highway systems, etc.

cells: Develop self-study, work independently, and work in groups.

column_map.CLOs Description: Develop self-study, work independently, and work in groups.

cells: Take personal responsibility, be partly responsible for the group, and accumulate experience to continue higher learning.

column_map.CLOs Description: Take personal responsibility, be partly responsible for the group, and accumulate experience to continue higher learning.

content.text: - Average score of course is the total points of rubrics multiplied by the respective weight of each rubric

column_map.Excellence 8.5 – 10 point: Attend all the sessions
column_map.Good 6.5 – 8.4 point: Absent 2 sessions
column_map.Fair 4.0 – 6.4 point: Absent 3 sessions
column_map.Poor 0 – 3.9 point: Absent 4 sessions

cells: Answer at least 2 questions from the lecturer and give at least 2 comments and/or feedback for the lessons, discussion, or presentation
Answer at least 1 question from the lecturer and give at least 1 comment and/or feedback for the lessons, discussion, or presentation
Answer at least 1 question from the lecturer or give at least 1 comment and/or feedback for the lessons, discussion, or presentation
No Answer for questions from the lecturer and give no comments and/or feedback for the lessons, discussion, or presentation

column_map.Good 6.5 – 8.4 point: Answer at least 1 question from the lecturer and give at least 1 comment and/or feedback for the lessons, discussion, or presentation

cells: Comprehensive collection of relevant data, thorough data preprocessing, handling missing values and outliers, ensuring data quality.
Sufficient data collection, adequate preprocessing techniques applied, reasonable handling of missing values and outliers.
Limited data collection, basic preprocessing steps taken, some issues with missing values and outliers.
Incomplete or insufficient data collection, inadequate preprocessing techniques, significant issues with missing values and outliers.

column_map.Excellence 8.5 – 10 point: Comprehensive collection of relevant data, thorough data preprocessing, handling missing values and outliers, ensuring data quality.
column_map.Good 6.5 – 8.4 point: Sufficient data collection, adequate preprocessing techniques applied, reasonable handling of missing values and outliers.
column_map.Fair 4.0 – 6.4 point: Limited data collection, basic preprocessing steps taken, some issues with missing values and outliers.
column_map.Poor 0 – 3.9 point: Incomplete or insufficient data collection, inadequate preprocessing techniques, significant issues with missing values and outliers.

cells: Extensive and insightful analysis of data patterns, identifying trends, seasonality, correlations, and anomalies, utilizing appropriate visualizations.
Satisfactory analysis of data patterns, identifying some trends, seasonality, correlations, and anomalies, utilizing visualizations effectively.
Basic analysis of data patterns, limited identification of trends, seasonality, correlations, and anomalies, utilizing basic visualizations.
Inadequate analysis of data patterns, unable to identify significant trends, seasonality, correlations, and anomalies, ineffective use of visualizations.

column_map.Excellence 8.5 – 10 point: Extensive and insightful analysis of data patterns, identifying trends, seasonality, correlations, and anomalies, utilizing appropriate visualizations.
column_map.Good 6.5 – 8.4 point: Satisfactory analysis of data patterns, identifying some trends, seasonality, correlations, and anomalies, utilizing visualizations effectively.
column_map.Fair 4.0 – 6.4 point: Basic analysis of data patterns, limited identification of trends, seasonality, correlations, and anomalies, utilizing basic visualizations.
column_map.Poor 0 – 3.9 point: Inadequate analysis of data patterns, unable to identify significant trends, seasonality, correlations, and anomalies, ineffective use of visualizations.

cells: Implementation of advanced time series or graph analysis models, accurate and precise predictions, thorough evaluation of model performance, consideration of appropriate metrics.
Implementation of suitable time series or graph analysis models, reasonably accurate predictions, evaluation of model performance using relevant metrics.
Basic implementation of time series or graph analysis models, limited accuracy in predictions, limited evaluation of model performance.
Inadequate implementation of time series or graph analysis models, inaccurate predictions, no or minimal evaluation of model performance.

column_map.Excellence 8.5 – 10 point: Implementation of advanced time series or graph analysis models, accurate and precise predictions, thorough evaluation of model performance, consideration of appropriate metrics.
column_map.Good 6.5 – 8.4 point: Implementation of suitable time series or graph analysis models, reasonably accurate predictions, evaluation of model performance using relevant metrics.
column_map.Fair 4.0 – 6.4 point: Basic implementation of time series or graph analysis models, limited accuracy in predictions, limited evaluation of model performance.
column_map.Poor 0 – 3.9 point: Inadequate implementation of time series or graph analysis models, inaccurate predictions, no or minimal evaluation of model performance.

cells: Comprehensive interpretation of results, meaningful insights and conclusions drawn from the analysis, identification of actionable recommendations.
Reasonable interpretation of results, some insights and conclusions drawn from the analysis, identification of potential recommendations.
Reasonable interpretation of results, some insights and conclusions drawn from the analysis, identification of potential recommendations.
Inadequate interpretation of results, lack of meaningful insights and conclusions, no or minimal recommendations.

column_map.Poor 0 – 3.9 point: Inadequate interpretation of results, lack of meaningful insights and conclusions, no or minimal recommendations.

cells: Clear and well-organized presentation of the project, effective communication of key findings, thorough documentation of methodologies and results.
Presentable project documentation, satisfactory communication of key findings, reasonable documentation of methodologies and results.
Basic project presentation, limited communication of findings, minimal documentation of methodologies and results.
Inadequate project presentation, unclear communication of findings, lack of documentation of methodologies and results.

Shows good knowledge of the concepts and theories in discrete mathematics, with the ability to apply them correctly and effectively.
Possesses a basic understanding of the concepts and theories in discrete mathematics, with limited or inaccurate application.
Displays minimal understanding of the concepts and theories in discrete mathematics and cannot apply them effectively.

Solves problems and exercises in discrete mathematics correctly and effectively.
Handles basic problems and exercises with some minor errors.
Unable to solve problems and exercises significantly in discrete mathematics

content.text: Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).

Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.

Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.

COURSE SYLLABUS (Issued with Decision number 976/QĐ-ĐHKTQD by NEU’s President dated August 30, 2023)

The course provides learners basic knowledge about sets, logic, mathematical systems, functions, series, relations, algorithms, number theory, counting problems, Dirichlet's principle, and graph theory.

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: The course provides learners basic knowledge about sets, logic, mathematical systems, functions, series, relations, algorithms, number theory, counting problems, Dirichlet's principle, and graph theory.

cells: The course equips learners with skills in the analysis, classification, and computation of objects: sets, propositions, functions, algorithms, strings, and graphs.

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: The course equips learners with skills in the analysis, classification, and computation of objects: sets, propositions, functions, algorithms, strings, and graphs.

cells: The course page allows learners to apply some algorithms on integers and graphs to solve practical problems such as encoding, finding the shortest path, coloring graphs, minimum tree frames, etc.

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: The course page allows learners to apply some algorithms on integers and graphs to solve practical problems such as encoding, finding the shortest path, coloring graphs, minimum tree frames, etc.

cells: Self-study, work independently, work in groups, take personal responsibility, and be partly responsible for the group, accumulate experience to continue higher learning.

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: Self-study, work independently, work in groups, take personal responsibility, and be partly responsible for the group, accumulate experience to continue higher learning.

cells: Understanding the law, civic responsibility; understanding professional behavior, and community interests. Understanding professional principles and ethics, time management, adapting to a changing work environment, adapting to globalization, and technology revolution 4.0

column_map.Objectives Goals Description: Understanding the law, civic responsibility; understanding professional behavior, and community interests. Understanding professional principles and ethics, time management, adapting to a changing work environment, adapting to globalization, and technology revolution 4.0

cells: Understand the concepts and computational bases of sets and propositions. Understand how sets are represented in computers and know the logic of google's search algorithm etc. Understand conflicting principles except for finding word-numbered parts of a set.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the concepts and computational bases of sets and propositions. Understand how sets are represented in computers and know the logic of google's search algorithm etc. Understand conflicting principles except for finding word-numbered parts of a set.

cells: Understand the fundamental objects of mathematical systems and methods of proof in mathematics.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the fundamental objects of mathematical systems and methods of proof in mathematics.

cells: Understand the basic concepts and properties of functions and binary relationships. Understand how to build several functions with high computational applications, such as a linear pseudo-random function (linear congruence method), a hash function (hash function), and a visa card number check function (calculation of credit card check number).

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the basic concepts and properties of functions and binary relationships. Understand how to build several functions with high computational applications, such as a linear pseudo-random function (linear congruence method), a hash function (hash function), and a visa card number check function (calculation of credit card check number).

cells: Understand the basic concepts and properties of algorithms, the operation of a basic algorithm such as a search, sorting, etc. Understand the object and function of a recursive algorithm.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the basic concepts and properties of algorithms, the operation of a basic algorithm such as a search, sorting, etc. Understand the object and function of a recursive algorithm.

cells: Understand basic concepts, properties, and algorithms in integers. Understand operations in the same radix system and how to convert between different radix systems. Know cryptography and understand how to build the RSA cryptosystem.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand basic concepts, properties, and algorithms in integers. Understand operations in the same radix system and how to convert between different radix systems. Know cryptography and understand how to build the RSA cryptosystem.

cells: Understand how to apply two basic counting principles, permutations, and combinations in counting problems. Understand combinatorics and position generation algorithms to solve some real-world problems. Know how to use Dirichlet's principle to show the existence of a combinatorial configuration.

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand how to apply two basic counting principles, permutations, and combinations in counting problems. Understand combinatorics and position generation algorithms to solve some real-world problems. Know how to use Dirichlet's principle to show the existence of a combinatorial configuration.

cells: Understand the basic concepts and properties of graph theory. Understand the application of graphs in information technology, computer science, and data science. Translating graph theory into solving practical problems

column_map.CLOs Description: Understand the basic concepts and properties of graph theory. Understand the application of graphs in information technology, computer science, and data science. Translating graph theory into solving practical problems

cells: Proficient in sets, propositions, functions, operations with integers, and radix conversion. Proficient in using the principles of counting, permutations, and combinations to solve counting problems. Have skills in calculating quantities in graphs such as degree, Incidence matrix, adjacency matrix, weight matrix, path, the weighted sum of a tree, tree depth, etc.

column_map.CLOs Description: Proficient in sets, propositions, functions, operations with integers, and radix conversion. Proficient in using the principles of counting, permutations, and combinations to solve counting problems. Have skills in calculating quantities in graphs such as degree, Incidence matrix, adjacency matrix, weight matrix, path, the weighted sum of a tree, tree depth, etc.

cells: Have the skills to read, understand, present, analyze, evaluate an algorithm, and implement it.

column_map.CLOs Description: Have the skills to read, understand, present, analyze, evaluate an algorithm, and implement it.

cells: Apply knowledge and some algorithms about integers to build cryptographic systems such as anagrams or RSA.

column_map.CLOs Description: Apply knowledge and some algorithms about integers to build cryptographic systems such as anagrams or RSA.

cells: Apply combinatorial and permutation algorithms to solve the bag problem, the traveler problem, etc.

column_map.CLOs Description: Apply combinatorial and permutation algorithms to solve the bag problem, the traveler problem, etc.

cells: Apply knowledge of graphs to solve practical problems, such as: Use the problem of finding the shortest path to find the path between two points on the map such as shortest distance or the least time or minimum cost, and using coloring problems in scheduling problems, wave frequency division, using the minimal spanning tree to design water pipelines, highway systems, etc.

column_map.CLOs Description: Apply knowledge of graphs to solve practical problems, such as: Use the problem of finding the shortest path to find the path between two points on the map such as shortest distance or the least time or minimum cost, and using coloring problems in scheduling problems, wave frequency division, using the minimal spanning tree to design water pipelines, highway systems, etc.

cells: Develop self-study, work independently, and work in groups.

column_map.CLOs Description: Develop self-study, work independently, and work in groups.

cells: Take personal responsibility, be partly responsible for the group, and accumulate experience to continue higher learning.

column_map.CLOs Description: Take personal responsibility, be partly responsible for the group, and accumulate experience to continue higher learning.

cells: Comprehensive collection of relevant data, thorough data preprocessing, handling missing values and outliers, ensuring data quality.
Sufficient data collection, adequate preprocessing techniques applied, reasonable handling of missing values and outliers.
Limited data collection, basic preprocessing steps taken, some issues with missing values and outliers.
Incomplete or insufficient data collection, inadequate preprocessing techniques, significant issues with missing values and outliers.

full_text:
Title: Discrete mathematic
Code: EP17.TOCB1107
Credit hours for teaching and learning activities:
Lecture: 45 hrs
Exercises on class: 5 hrs
Presentation and Discussion: 3 hrs
Exercise and discussion: 7 hrs
Self-study: 90 hrs
Parallel course(s): None
Prerequisite course(s): None
Department conducting the course: Information Technology
Kind of the course:
Course language: In English
A Basic module of the bachelor's degree program modules is related to information technology, computer science, data science and fintech.... Discrete mathematics is a branch of Mathematics that studies discrete rather than continuous structures. The course also aims to train thinking capacity and calculation skills and improve the ability to apply mathematical knowledge to analyze and research problems in information technology. The course equips learners with the necessary knowledge, skills, and competencies to study and research related subjects in the training program and continue to higher education. At the end of the course, learners can do a graph network data analysis project.
Course outline:
Logic and Set
Proofs
Functions, Strings and Relation
Algorithms
Introduction to Number Theory
Counting problems and Dirichlet’s Principle
Graph Theory
Tree
Seminar talks: The goal is to introduce state-of-the-art applications of discrete mathematics in the modern technology. Besides, invited student-speakers can be included to share about their scientific projects related to the course’s materials.
Outcomes assessment:
(10%) Participant
(40%) Quiz + Midterm: quiz 1 (10%), quiz 2 (10%), project presentation (5%) and midterm (15%).
(50%) Final Exam
[1] Richard Johnsonbaugh (2018), Discrete Mathematics, Eighth Edition, Pearson.
[2] Kenneth H. Rosen (2019), Discrete Mathematics and Its Applications, Eighth Edition, McGraw-Hill Education.
Table 5. Course learning outcomes (CLOs)
* Assessment methods:
- Grading: 10
- Average score of course is the total points of rubrics multiplied by the respective weight of each rubric
* Assessment summary:
Table 6. Assessment summary
Rubric 1: Participant
Rubric 2: Project
Rubric 3: Midterm and Final exam
Table 7. Course outline
Table 8.1. Lesson plan for the course
Students are allowed to take the final exam if their attendance score reaches 5 points or more (on the scale of 10).
Students are responsible for attending all classes. In case of absence from school due to force majeure reasons, sufficient and reasonable proofs must be provided. For each absence, 1 point will be deducted 1 point. Students who miss any classes more than 3 times, with or without reason, will be considered as failing to complete the course and have to re-register.
Students will be awarded points for constructive comments these points are added to attendance points and group assignments.
Groups who do not submit the group work will receive a score of 0 (zero). Late submissions will be deducted for each day of late submission.
The course is conducted on the principle of respecting learners and lecturers. Any behaviour that affects the teaching and learning process is strictly prohibited.
Students must come to class on time. Students who are late more than 10 minutes after class starts will not be allowed to attend the class. Do not make noise and affect others during the learning process.
Laptops and tablets are only used for the purpose of taking notes for and calculating for lectures and exercises, absolutely forbidden to use for other purposes.
